body: If you scroll down to the last dropdown menu, and select a topic from there, the sidebar will jump back to the top. Although the dropdown would still be open, you would need to scroll down to go to the selected topic.

@maosongfu Heron currently requires a patched version of thrift 0.5.0 that is only available at maven.twttr.com, which is a public repo. @longdafeng if you're environment can't connect there, you can download the artifact and upload it to your local maven repo.
I'm not that familiar with the syntax of either but these changes seem reasonable.
@saileshmittal I added a `scrollTo` line in `sidebar.js` to address this issue. Give it a try at the same link above. It's not perfect but I think that it does help.
The python BUILD parts that I commented on in #658 have been addressed. I have not reviewed the code itself.
@lucperkins looks like your site isn't showing the changed version anymore, but the formats above LGTM.
@billonahill Yeah, unfortunately my personal site is showing the changes in #835 at the moment.

@mlinge pex files include the dependencies (in this case pyyaml) so reinstalling it on your machine shouldn't make a difference. I would recommend looking at the version currently being bundled and checking its compatibility with your version of Ubuntu.

@Jonathan-Wei best way to debug this would be to follow the code from this line in `bazel_configure.py`:

```
  env_map['AUTOMAKE'] = discover_tool('automake', 'Automake', 'AUTOMAKE', '1.9.6')
```

It calls `discover_tool`, which fails to find anything in `discover_program`. Add some print debugging in `discover_program` and `real_program_path` to uncover the issue: 
https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/bazel_configure.py#L212

@zuyu looks like `3rdparty/pex/_pex` failed to execute without much messaging as to why. Specfically this:

```
cd /private/var/tmp/_bazel_zzhang/3964dd02d192385870c24d7a89344f18/heron && \
  exec env - \
  bazel-out/local_darwin-fastbuild/bin/3rdparty/pex/_pex --not-zip-safe --entry-point \
  heron.ui.src.python.main bazel-out/local_darwin-fastbuild/bin/heron/ui/src/python/heron-ui.pex bazel-out/local_darwin-fastbuild/bin/heron/ui/src/python/heron-ui.pex.manifest
```

Best way to debug would be to add some print statements into `3rdparty/pex/_pex` to see identify it's failing and improve the messaging.

The error being **HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError**. Is it possible that this error is caused because zookeeper was not setup for State Manager?

We have this similar problem when compiling the binaries on one platform and executing it on another platform. One thing we can do is recompiling the whole heron project on your host, and then install the compiled the binaries.

This review changes CI to audit all java files at once. The java checkstyle takes 7 seconds, but the build still take 42 minutes.

@maosongfu in #818 the java checkstyle is done once for the entire repo at the start, which takes 7 seconds, but the build still take 42 minutes. How did you assert that 20-30 minutes would be saved without checkstyles?

Thanks for clarifying. Really we want to have the release in the docs align with the git tag. So if you checkout a git tag for a release, the docs are properly labeled. With this approach they won't be. Could we instead update the release process to include changing the version in `config.yaml`? Either automatically via a release script (ideal) or manually via documented process.

That's great, thanks for the patch. I'll review this shortly. In the meanwhile would you please accept the CLA yet from here:
http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/contributors/community/

@billonahill How is this approach different from what you're proposing? This approach determines the current Heron version via Git tags and then updates the version value in the website config.

Whether this script is called during the broader Heron release process is up to others, but as for the `make site` process this seems to do precisely what you're calling for.
Sure, CLA accepted!

@billonahill To be honest, I had reservations about the pull request model for this and my doubts have been confirmed. I tried to merge with `upstream/gh-pages` here and that generated 100+ merge conflicts, which makes sense because there will _always_ and by necessity be merge conflicts on this branch because we're dealing with generated content, not source content. It's not clear that merging makes sense to begin with because there's nothing to be gained by merging with files that are meant to be simply obliterated when `make site` is run.

And so I think that the current approach of force pushing the generated `public` folder to the `upstream/gh-pages` branch is the only viable approach.
The release tag in git should already include an updated config.yaml file to have a matching version.

@billonahill But the issue with that approach is that there's nothing to ensure that that happens. @kramasamy explicitly asked me to create a script that automates keeping the two in sync. To be honest, I don't really mind either way; I'm just taking cues from the project lead.

the c++ binaries need to be statically linked - we do mostly static option and because of this standard libraries and libunwind are not statically linked.

I add some print to debugging in real_progream_path and which method!

```
path is /opt/local/bin

candidate is /opt/local/bin/cmake
isfile : False ,access enough: False :
is_exc method return is False
isfile : False ,access enough: False :
candidate is /opt/local/bin/cmake
isfile : False ,access enough: False :
is_exc method return is False
isfile : False ,access enough: False :
```

```
def which(program):
  def is_exe(fpath):
    print("isfile : %s ,access enough: %s :" % (os.path.isfile(fpath) , os.access(fpath, os.X_OK)))
    return os.path.isfile(fpath) and os.access(fpath, os.X_OK)

  def ext_candidates(fpath):
    yield fpath
    for ext in os.environ.get("PATHEXT", "").split(os.pathsep):
      yield fpath + ext

  fpath, fname = os.path.split(program)
  print("fpath %s fname %s" %(fpath,fname))
  if fpath:
    if is_exe(program):
      return program
  else:
    for path in os.environ["PATH"].split(os.pathsep):
      print("path is %s " % path)
      exe_file = os.path.join(path, program)
      print("exe_file is %s" % exe_file)
      for candidate in ext_candidates(exe_file):
        print("candidate is %s " % candidate)
        print("is_exc method return is %s" % is_exe(candidate))
        if is_exe(candidate):
          return candidate

  return None
```

@aaronshan - this is because the file times are set to be epoch - while making the tar packages. Would appreciate a patch.
@maosongfu / @nlu90 - could you help on the simulation mode?
You're comparing two different things. `bazel_configure.py` is checking `/opt/local/bin/cmake`, but you're checking `/usr/local/bin/automake`.

@lucperkins if you're getting a merge conflict, I will too and we won't be able to commit. (I confirmed this)

I suspect the conflicts are because your remote has build date tags inserted into pages that conflict with the upstream remote. To resolve you can reset with the upstream remote and rebuild and you won't have conflicts.

Assuming `origin` is your fork and `upstream` is twitters:

```
$ cd workspace/heron
$ git pull upstream/master
$ cd website/public
$ git pull upstream/gh-pages
$ git reset upstream/gh-pages --hard
# push this to your gh-pages fork and verify your remote is in sync with the upstream
$ git status # should show everything clean
$ cd .. && make site && cd -
# commit to your fork again and you should have a clean diff for a PR. You might need to force push:
$ git push -f origin gh-pages
```

Now you can make a clean PR.

might be related:

> Apple fully supports static libraries; if you want to create one, just start with the appropriate Xcode project or target template.
> 
> Apple does not support statically linked binaries on Mac OS X. A statically linked binary assumes binary compatibility at the kernel system call interface, and we do not make any guarantees on that front. Rather, we strive to ensure binary compatibility in each dynamically linked system library and framework.

from https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/qa/qa1118/_index.html

@aaronshan 
Checked the heron-executor.stdout, and found:

heron-tmaster exited with status 256
stmgr-1 exited with status 256

So pretty sure the issue is caused by lacking dependencies to start C++ program;  but it is wired that log-info is missing in heron-executor.stderr, so currently no way to know what those dependencies are.

You can diagnose by run the stream mgr's cmd directly in terminal, check the output and figure out the lacking dependencies.

We are working in progress to relief your issues too:
1. #505 
2. #853

@Jonathan-Wei 

Unlike Storm, heron itself is a library.

To run topologies in a distributed environment, you need to setup:
1. [scheduler](http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/operators/deployment/schedulers/aurora/) for scheduling jobs 
2. [uploader](http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/operators/deployment/uploaders/hdfs/) for uploading and downloading your topology file, heron-core file
3. [statemanager](http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/operators/deployment/statemanagers/zookeeper/) for managing the states during topology running

@jipinxieshen 
Checked the heron-executor.stdout provided by @aaronshan , and found:

heron-tmaster exited with status 256
stmgr-1 exited with status 256

So pretty sure the issue is caused by lacking dependencies to start C++ program; but it is wired that log-info is missing in heron-executor.stderr, so currently no way to know what those dependencies are.

You can diagnose by run the stream mgr's cmd directly in terminal, check the output and figure out the lacking dependencies.

We are working in progress to relief your issues too:
1. #505 
2. #853
BTW, we currently have built-in support for aurora and slurm. Mesos and YARN are working in process and coming soon.
#853 is also working in progress.

@alanngai , As I mentioned before, we are not following any particular python code styles, but we will be following [twitter guidelines](https://github.com/twitter/commons/blob/master/src/python/twitter/common/styleguide.md) eventually. One of the things I wanted to mention is the 2-space indentation, that you have already done, and 4-space indent for wrapped lines, like lines following an open bracket. Can you add that check as well?

If you want to compile for centos 6, you need to compile bazel. Bazel binaries do not work for centos6. Otherwise rest of the code should compile without any issues. We have tried in centos5 and it works.

@Jonathan-Wei - you can read the sections on Deployment for understanding how to deploy it multi-node cluster. 
- Since Heron does not have a scheduler of its own - you need to have a scheduler installed. Currently, we support Aurora/Mesos - you need to install Aurora as in http://aurora.apache.org/
- You need a zookeeper installed in some node.

Once you have both follow the configuration 

https://github.com/twitter/heron/tree/master/heron/config/src/yaml/conf/aurora
@nlu90 - can you please check and get to the bottom of the issue?
Otherwise LGTM. Can you also fix why travis build is failing?

build is still busted.  The build log indicates a problem executing a test topology, but doesn't say exactly what failed or why (see below).  The only thing I can think of is the addition of checkstyle.ini inside of tools/python that I added, and maybe that needs to be packaged in somehow.  I'm not familiar with how the build and test system works to do this.  Will need some help on this.  For reference, part of this PR was to modify the tools/java/.../PythonCheckstyle.java:84 where I added an additional command line parameter to read the checkstyle.ini file

```
  // Create and run the command
  List<String> commandBuilder = new ArrayList<>();
  commandBuilder.add(pylintFile);
  commandBuilder.add("--rcfile=" + PYLINT_RCFILE); // tools/python/checkstyle.ini
  commandBuilder.addAll(sourceFiles);
  runLinter(commandBuilder);
```

this seems to work fine locally when I run the linter, but maybe it breaks the build somehow?

Great point. Configs that we supply are examples which is bundled in the package. The expectation is that the user provided config will be in different directory - for example - you can have a directory called "~/clusters" under which two different directories 'devcluster' and 'prodcluster'. When you issue a command, you need to do the following:

heron activate devcluster --config-path ~/clusters ExclamationTopology

note that --config-path option need to be provided in all the commands. To avoid repetition, we are working on a user specific ~/.heronrc (that allows specifying the config path once). The commands will use ~/.heronrc in order to determine correct config-path.

Hope this helps!
@DarinJ - any other suggestions are welcome as well!

3Q guys!

@maosongfu thanks. I have resolved this problem. For centos6, It need to upgrade gcc and glibc verion. Except this, it need to install libunwind.
If cannot find libunwind, It will report error like this:

```
./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: error while loading shared libraries: libunwind.so.8: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

If use default gcc and glibc, It will report error like this:

```
./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.18' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.14' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `CXXABI_1.3.5' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.19' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: /lib64/libc.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.14' not found (required by ./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr)

```

After resolve above all problems, Heron will work in centos6(**even if use install-file that complied on centos7**).

I've got this error by running the stmgr-1 directly : 

```
./heron-core/bin/heron-stmgr: error while loading shared libraries: libunwind.so.8: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

Resolved by installing libunwind

@Jonathan-Wei 
I got the same problem.
Following change can fix this issue.

```
diff --git a/3rdparty/java/BUILD b/3rdparty/java/BUILD
index a3a3688..e3250f4 100644
--- a/3rdparty/java/BUILD
+++ b/3rdparty/java/BUILD
@@ -99,8 +99,10 @@ java_library(
     srcs = [ "Empty.java" ],
     exports = [
         "@powermock-api-mockito//jar",
+       "@powermock-api-support//jar",
         "@powermock-core//jar",
         "@powermock-module-junit4//jar",
+       "@powermock-module-junit4-common//jar",
     ],
     deps = [
         "@powermock-api-mockito//jar",
```
@jipinxieshen If you use centos7, you nedd install libunwind, If you use centos6, you need install libunwind, upgrade your gcc and glibc version.
